Reality Check

I wanted to put this out here and see what happens.
 
 We have all heard about the steriod problem in Baseball. Here is my question. Would the 'old timer' like Babe Ruth, had they had them available, have taken steriods to inhance their game?
 
 I mean, come on, its not like these great heros of the diamond were the most clean cut guys. Remember the 'Black Sox'? Babe Ruth himself was known for his rather questionable behavior. 
 
 My point, if there has to be one, is that while we are screaming about records being broken unfairly I think its worth a thought to spotlight the record holders and consider what may have been if the pioneers had access to these products.
 
 So, whats your opinion?

post_info.post_title: What if Babe Ruth took steriods?

syklopps61

I don't think they ever would have considered steroids had they been available. I personally think that yes, some good, clean living combined with their natural abilities, the records set/achievements by these true legends would be even more unattainable by today's athletes. No doubt they have the physical ability, but the love of the game is gone, and that lack of motivation is replaced by a drug to attain that high level of performance. The statisitics achieved by these legends were accomplished in a time where it was available to all...for example, the era of the live ball I believe it's called, when Babe Ruth started hitting all those home runs, that same live ball was there to hit by EVERYONE else, which makes his, and others, achievements so truly remarkable. These guys today shoot themselves up to excel, while others that choose to play the game by the rules are considered "not as good"...go figure
billsco

We can agree the Bambino was no angel; he apparently was quite crass. But I don't know if your question is germane or not. He didn't cheat, as far as we know, and that's that. 
 
 Fans of the game take their statistics seriously, and I think what's occured is a real travesty. Your question looks suspiciously like it is designed to drag the legends through the mud in order to make the present-day cheaters look less reprehensible. I'm not sure if that is your intent, but it isn't working for me.
zachvac

You do have to applaud the people who work hard every day and stretch their physical limits without breaking the rules (Schilling in last year's series).

I think all the Commissioners (NHL, MLB, NBA, etc) could take a lesson from Paul T. (can't spell his last name) of the NFL.  The NFL is the true "America's game". It has been for years.

billsco

I started a thread in the Sports section--admittedly tongue in cheek--that asked to reconsider Barry Bonds use of steroids, but no one responded. The newest allegations about widespread use in the major leagues (it was even in the clubhouse coffee) would seem to indicate Bonds was only leveling the field. How would you like to face a juiced pitcher with no juice yourself?
Ooaman

How would you like to face a juiced pitcher with no juice yourself?

 I'm just curious why a pitcher would need steroids? I can understand why the batters would want to use steroids so they can hit more balls. But I don't see where steroids would help pitchers.
 Of course, I'm thinking American League mentality, not National League mentality.
zachvac

I'm just curious why a pitcher would need steroids? I can understand why the batters would want to use steroids so they can hit more balls. But I don't see where steroids would help pitchers.
 Of course, I'm thinking American League mentality, not National League mentality.

 
 There was an article about that in last month's ESPN magazine actually. Basically it gives the pitcher a bigger advantage than a hitter. They are able to bounce back quicker, and recover. Basically your arm isn't meant for throwing 90 miles an hour for up to 90-100 pitches. So most pitchers take several days recovering (usually they have 4 or 5 man rotations), and if they don't take care of their arm they could ruin it for the season. Steroids helps their muscle recover from the strain on it that day and especially for closers who may have to throw 3-4 days in a row depending on the score of the games, it could help them so much. It can help them throw more pitches, bounce back quicker, and not feel like :xcensored the morning after. The article described it as "pitcher's hangover".
zachvac

Is it really love of the game or is it more the attitude of get what you can WHILE you can? The choice to become great I believe is more motivated by love of money than of the game.

 
 Actually I agree with this and it's a real shame that baseball players in the MLB are in it for the money. There are still some out there who play it because it's fun. It's a very challenging sport, mentally as well as physically. In my opinion working at it is one of the most rewarding parts of the game. Now I understand these people still work at it, but there's a difference between stretching physical limitations in a healthy way rather than a way that can ruin your body. If steroids didn't do that, they would be legal. But people are willing to throw their future away for the present: money and fame.
zachvac

but they don't enforce it very well at all. Before the season they can only test 5% of the players max, and during the season, once you've been tested you can't be tested for the rest of the season. I mean if the teacher left the room during the SAT's, do you honestly expect everyone to sit there and not cheat, when doing well can help them get a better standing in life? Steroids is just an extreme. You pay a bigger price for it, but you also get better results.
electrolyte

I mean, come on, its not like these great heros of the diamond were the most clean cut guys. Remember the 'Black Sox'? Babe Ruth himself was known for his rather questionable behavior.

 I'm going to respond to something other than your main point, just because I feel it should be done.
 
 Not being clean-cut is not a damnable offense in baseball. Ty Cobb was still a great hitter and runner despite being a terribly racist son of a bitch. Babe Ruth was a great pitcher before he became known for being a great pitcher, even if he slept around and really was "the noisiest [F-er] in the world" (as described by a roommate).
 
 Regarding the Black Sox, while I greatly dislike the decisions that they made, one familiar with the history recognizes why they risked so much. Comiskey did everything he could to save money, even if it meant ticking off the nation's best team badly enough to make them want to get back at him.

What they do off the field is their business, but when it's on the field or it effects their on-field performance, than it's baseball's business.
